string-array.item: Loving your husband begins in your heart and mind.Today, write down 20 things about your husband that you are truly grateful for.

Sometimes it is true what they say - the wayto a man’s heart is through his stomach! You may be a great cook in the kitchen, or you might be a type of person who would rather order delivery! Either way, your husband will appreciate this gesture. Tell him you want to cook him something special, and ask him what he would like to have. Do your best to find a good recipe. Cook the meal as best you can, lay out the fancy plates, and set the table extra fancy. Even if the food doesn’t turn out the way you would like, he will definitely appreciate your effort in creating a special date night.

Movie date! Watch a movie (not a show!) with your husband. This can be at home or at a movie theater. Make sure he knows that it is his turn to pick. If he chooses something you don’t like, that’s ok! Try to be cheerful - do not complain! It is a chance to expand your tastes, and also to practice showing your husband that you care about his interests even if yours are different. What did you watch?

A husband should love you no matter what you look like! But at the same time, men tend to be more visually oriented than women. Today, take special consideration to improve your physical appearance in a way that your husband tends to appreciate. For example, this could be wearing a dress he likes, working out to get better in shape, doing your hair in a way that he really likes, putting on make-up, or getting rid of a piece of clothing that he really hates. Your husband should love you regardless, but he will appreciate the effort you take and the attention you give to his suggestions.

Today, plan a really fancy date with your husband. It’s ok to spend money to have a good time with your spouse now and then! Think of something where you both can really dress to impress. You want to be able to wear your nicest dress, your best jewelry, have a good time, and be reminded of how lucky you are to have each other! Have fun!

Sometimes loving your husband means you first have to take time to love yourself. Today, take time to do something that really refreshes your spirit. Get some exercise, do some meditation, hang out with friends, read some books, get out in the sun… find something that really brings you joy and commit to taking care of yourself today so you have energy and gratefulness.

One of the most important things we can do to build a healthy marriage is truly listen to each other. Today, check in with your husband. How is he doing? What’s been going on in his life lately? Really listen, make eye contact, asking questions, making sure you understand where he is coming from. If he is distressed, sympathize but encourage him, and ask if there is anything you can do to help. If he is doing great, be happy for him. How is he?

Find a time with your husband that you can set aside to talk face to face. Tell him that you want to love him better, and be a better wife for him. Ask your him how he feels you have been treating him. Ask him what he thinks you can do to be a better wife. Do not criticize or become defensive, as he may say some things that are difficult to hear. Just listen. Thank him for his honest feedback, and be willing to tell him that you are planning to make changes in your life on those issues. Afterward, write down some of the major points here. How can you practically address his concerns?

Write your husband a letter. Men desire respect and gratitude. Tell him all the reasons you are proud of him. Tell him what it is about him that you are grateful for. Tell him you love him. Give him the letter.

It is important that your husband knows he comes first in your life, and one of the best ways to do this is by giving him your undivided attention. Today, whenever your husband speaks to you, drop what you are doing, turn toward him, make eye contact, and truly listen, taking the time to hear out all that is on his mind. How did it go?

Make time to go for a walk together and hold his hand. Phones stay at home. Going for a walk is a great to get out of the house, enjoy the outdoors, and have time talking about whatever comes to mind. Many couples do this on a regular basis. How did it go?

Write down some of the things your husband does around the house that you really appreciate. Get a post it note or piece of paper, choose one of those things, and write a note expressing your thanks. Post it somewhere he will see it - possibly in a place right next to where the chore starts!

Today, you get to take personal inventory. How do you think you have been as a wife? Write down 3 strengths and 3 weakness. Choose one of those weaknesses. Tell your husband that you know you have not been what you want to be in that particular area, and apologize if this has hurt him. Tell him you will try to make improvements upon it in the future, and give him specific examples of what you plan to do to make that happen.

It is important that your husband knows you speak well of him in front of others. Today, publicly express gratitude for something about your husband in front of your family or friends. Yes, Facebook counts too.
Write him a letter, telling him one of your favorite memories together and leave it somewhere he may not notice it right away - perhaps in the car, in his wallet, or a journal.
Take time to hold your husband’s hand or give him a hug today. It is important that we show physical affection that is also non-sexual. Write down what you did, and how he responded.
Try a new food together! Adventure is the spice of life, and it is fun and important to create memories with your husband.

Is there something your husband has done that has hurt you? Write it down here. Today, realize that no one is perfect. Forgive your husband in your heart, as you would want to be forgiven. If you need to forgive him in person, do so and write about the response. When finished, write \"Forgiven\".

Physical intimacy is extremely important to most men - even if they do not express it. They experience emotional closeness and connection through physical intimacy. Today, have a frank and honest discussion with your husband about your physical initmacy. Tell him to be honest, and be honest yourself. Keep an attitude of willingness to make changes.
Is there a certain outfit that your husband really wishes you would wear, but for some reason, you never wear it? Give it a shot! Even it’s just around the house, he will appreciate it!
The next time you and your husband disagree about something, let him win! He will feel respected, validated, and trusted.

"We all know that waiting until the end of the night to have sex often means you fall asleep before you get to it," says Ian Kerner, a relationship and sex expert, and author. Try an alternative time to have sex — your lunch hour, on a Saturday afternoon when the house is empty or by slipping into his morning shower. If evenings are truly the only available time, make it a priority—get into bed earlier, forego the flannel PJs and make an event out of it.

Absence makes the heart grow fonder. Literally! There is a reason why the old sentiment is such a classic. Spending time apart gives you a chance to reflect on your relationship, gets you out of your routine and, most obviously (and perhaps most significantly!), gives you an opportunity to miss each other! Get on the phone and schedule that girls\' weekend that you and your friends keep talking about, visit your mother or give yourself the gift of some time alone. A little bit of time spent apart will make a big difference in how you reconnect afterwards.
Couples that play together, stay together! Today, do a puzzle or play a game together! Have some fun!
Sometimes it’s nice to just get out of the house, try a new place, and have a chat. Ask your husband out for a coffee date! If he can’t do one today, put one in the calendar!
Write down some things you appreciate about your husband’s physical appearance. Look him in the eye and compliment her on this.
Today, surprise your husband, and randomly grab his butt sometime during the day! Alternatively, take a shower together!
Do you remember the time before being married, when you were dating? You used to flirt, even though you may not know it! Pick a favorite flirtation and do it again today.
Suggest reading a book of shared interest or an article that is interesting to both of you. You can read it aloud together, or read it on your own - but make a point to talk about it!

This final challenge is difficult. Find a time with your husband that you can set aside to talk face to face. Ask your husband how he feels you have been treating him. Ask him what you can do to make him feel more loved. Ask him what you can do to be a better wife. Do not criticize, just listen. Thank him for his honest feedback, and be willing to tell him that you are planning to make changes in your life on those issues. Afterward, write down some of the major points here. How can you practically address his concerns?

resources.string: \"I take thee to be my wedded husband, to have and to hold from this day forward, for better, for worse, for richer, for poorer, in sickness and in health, to love and to cherish, till death do us part, according to God\'s holy ordinance; and thereto I pledge thee my faith.\" \n\n — Traditional Wedding Vow
\"Love is always bestowed as a gift -freely, willingly, and without expectation. We don’t love to be loved, we love to love.\" \n\n — Leo Buscagalia
\"To get the full value of joy you must have someone to divide it with.\" \n\n — Mark Twain
\"Death cannot stop true love. All it can do is delay it for a while.\" \n\n — Wesley, The Princess Bride
\"My most brilliant achievement was my ability to persuade my wife to marry me.\" \n\n — Winston Churchill
\"Husbands, love your wives, just as Christ loved the church and gave himself up for her.\" \n\n — Ephesians 5:25

"Two are better than one, 
 because they have a good return for their labor:
 If either of them falls down,
 one can help the other up.
 But pity anyone who falls
 and has no one to help them up.
 Also, if two lie down together, they will keep warm.
 But how can one keep warm alone?
 Though one may be overpowered,
 two can defend themselves.
 A cord of three strands is not quickly broken." 

 — Ephesians 4:9-12
\"Whatever we do or suffer for a friend is pleasant, because love is the principal cause of pleasure.\" \n\n — Thomas Aquinas
\"Darkness cannot drive out darkness; only light can do that. Hate cannot drive out hate; only love can do that.\" \n\n — Martin Luther King Jr.

"Honor her for all that her hands have done, 
 and let her works bring her praise at the city gate." 

 — Proverbs 31:31
\"You come to love not by finding the perfect person, but by learning to see an imperfect person perfectly.\" \n\n — Sam Keen
\"There are only two days in the year that nothing can be done. One is called Yesterday and the other is called Tomorrow.\" \n\n — Dalai Lama XIV
\"Marriage is a workshop… where the husband works and the wife shops.\" \n\n — The Internet
\"I destroy my enemy if I make him my friend.\" \n\n — Abraham Lincoln
\"I pronounce you man and wife. You may now change your facebook status.\" \n\n — Anonymous
\"I am my beloved\'s, and my beloved is mine.\" \n\n — Song of Solomon 8:3
\"I would rather share one lifetime with you than face all the ages of this world alone.\" \n\n — Arwen, The Fellowship of The Ring
\"Be completely humble and gentle; be patient, bearing with one another in love.\" \n\n — Ephesians 4:2

\"Love is a mighty pretty thing; but like all other delicious things, it is cloying; and when the first transports of the passion begins to subside, which it assuredly will do, and yield, oftentimes too late, to more sober reflections, it serves to evince, that love is too dainty a food to live upon alone, and ought not to be considered farther than as a necessary ingredient for that matrimonial happiness which results from a combination of causes.\" \n\n — George Washington
\"Stay with me to-night; you must see me die. I have long had the taste of death on my tongue, I smell death, and who will stand by my Constanze, if you do not stay?\" \n\n — Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart

\"It takes courage to love, but pain through love is the purifying fire which those who love generously know. We all know people who are so much afraid of pain that they shut themselves up like clams in a shell and, giving out nothing, receive nothing and therefore shrink until life is a mere living death.\" \n\n — Eleanor Roosevelt

\"I believe myself that romantic love is the source of the most intense delights that life has to offer. In the relation of a man and woman who love each other with passion and imagination and tenderness, there is something of inestimable value, to be ignorant of which is a great misfortune to any human being.\" \n\n — Bertrand Russell

\"Love is a fruit in season at all times, and within reach of every hand. Anyone may gather it and no limit is set. Everyone can reach this love through meditation, spirit of prayer, and sacrifice, by an intense inner life.\" \n\n — Mother Theresa
"Love your neighbor as you love yourself." \n\n — Jesus, Matthew 22:39

\"The Caladrius is a bird of which it is related that, when it is carried into the presence of a sick person, if the sick man is going to die, the bird turns away its head and never looks at him; but if the sick man is to be saved the bird never loses sight of him but is the cause of curing him of all his sickness. Like unto this is the love of virtue. It never looks at any vile or base thing, but rather clings always to pure and virtuous things and takes up its abode in a noble heart; as the birds do in green woods on flowery branches. And this Love shows itself more in adversity than in prosperity; as light does, which shines most where the place is darkest.\" \n\n — Leonardo Davinci
\"Marriage is when a man looses his bachelors degree and woman gets her masters degree.\" \n \n — Rama Kochar

\"If I speak in the tongues of men or of angels, but do not have love, I am only a resounding gong or a clanging cymbal. If I have the gift of prophecy and can fathom all mysteries and all knowledge, and if I have a faith that can move mountains, but do not have love, I am nothing. If I give all I possess to the poor and give over my body to hardship that I may boast, but do not have love, I gain nothing.\" \n\n — 1 Cor. 13:1-3

\"But love your enemies, do good to them, and lend to them without expecting to get anything back. Then your reward will be great, and you will be children of the Most High, because he is kind to the ungrateful and wicked.\" \n\n — Jesus, Luke 6:35

\"My very dear Sarah: …[ ]… The memories of the blissful moments I have spent with you come creeping over me, and I feel most gratified to God and to you that I have enjoyed them for so long. And hard it is for me to give them up and burn to ashes the hopes of future years, when, God willing, we might still have lived and loved together, and seen our sons grown up to honorable manhood, around us. I have, I know, but few and small claims upon Divine Providence, but something whispers to me — perhaps it is the wafted prayer of my little Edgar, that I shall return to my loved ones unharmed. If I do not my dear Sarah, never forget how much I love you, and when my last breath escapes me on the battle field, it will whisper your name. Forgive my many faults and the many pains I have caused you. How thoughtless and foolish I have often times been! How gladly would I wash out with my tears every little spot upon your happiness …\" \n\n — Sullivan Ballou
\"Greater love has no one than this, that someone lay down his life for his friends.\" \n\n — Jesus, John 15:13
